Enums/VSAlertActionStyle.html.name: VSAlertActionStyle
Enums/VSAlertActionStyle.html.abstract: An enuration for the various UI styles of VSAlertAction

Enums/VSAlertControllerStyle.html.name: VSAlertControllerStyle
Enums/VSAlertControllerStyle.html.abstract: An enuration for the various ui styles of VSAlertController

Classes/VSAlertController.html#/c:objc(c.name: titleTextColor
Classes/VSAlertController.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: The color of the title text used by alert controllers. The default value is nil. If nil is specified when an alert controller is displayed, VSAlertController.textColor’s value is used instead. (Class property, applies to all instances created after change)

Classes/VSAlertController.html#/c:objc(c.name: textColor
Classes/VSAlertController.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: The color of the text used by alert controllers. (Class property, applies to all instances created after change)

Classes/VSAlertController.html#/c:objc(c.name: titleTextFont
Classes/VSAlertController.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: The font of the title used by alert controllers. The default value is the system font at size 17.0f. (Class property, applies to all instances created after change)

Classes/VSAlertController.html#/c:objc(c.name: textFont
Classes/VSAlertController.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: The font of the text used by alert controllers. The default value is the the system font at size 15.0f (Class property, applies to all instances created after change)

Classes/VSAlertController.html#/c:objc(c.name: textFields
Classes/VSAlertController.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: An array of UITextFields visible on the alert

Classes/VSAlertController.html#/c:objc(c.name: alertMaskBackground
Classes/VSAlertController.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: The background view of the alert. It’s default image is set to nil, and its default background color is set to #FFFFFF with an alpha component of 0.5. You can change it’s background color or assign an image if you prefer an different background for your alert.

Classes/VSAlertController.html#/c:objc(c.name: +alertControllerWithTitle:description:image:style:
Classes/VSAlertController.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: A factory method to create a new alert. The alert is dynamically sized based on your initialization paramaters

Classes/VSAlertController.html#/c:objc(c.name: +resetStyleToDefaults
Classes/VSAlertController.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: Reset class property customization to its default settings

Classes/VSAlertController.html#/c:objc(c.name: -addAction:
Classes/VSAlertController.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: Add an action to the alert controller. See VSAlertAction’s documentation for more information

Classes/VSAlertController.html#/c:objc(c.name: -addTextField:
Classes/VSAlertController.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: Add a text field to the alert controller. Rather than instantiating the UITextField yourself, use the configuration block (which provides you an already initialized UITextField, and make your customizations there. Unlike in PMAlertController, you can re-assign the the UITextField’s delegate property – VSAlertController does not make use of UITextField to infer when to dismiss and show the keyboard.

Classes/VSAlertAction.html#/c:objc(cs)VS.name: action
Classes/VSAlertAction.html#/c:objc(cs)VS.abstract: The block to be executed when the action is selected by the user

Classes/VSAlertAction.html#/c:objc(cs)VS.name: style
Classes/VSAlertAction.html#/c:objc(cs)VS.abstract: The the UI style of the action

Classes/VSAlertAction.html#/c:objc(cs)VS.name: +alertActionWithTitle:style:action:
Classes/VSAlertAction.html#/c:objc(cs)VS.abstract: Factory method to create an alert action

Classes/VSAlertAction.html.name: VSAlertAction
Classes/VSAlertAction.html.abstract: VSAlertAction is a specialized subclass used to configure a VSAlertController.

Classes/VSAlertController.html.name: VSAlertController
Classes/VSAlertController.html.abstract: VSAlertController is a drop-in replacement for UIAlertController with a bit more customization and better looks. It’s largely based on Codeido’s PMAlertController, but has been re-written in Objective-C rather than Swift, and supports a few more features like dynamically sorted alert actions and a destructive action style that was missing in PMAlertController. It doesn’t requrie a separate XIB file for better potability, and uses the system font by default for a more vanilla look. VSAlertController can can be customized at the class level, so you can make any/all UI changes once.
